anchor.surface_text: Rule 161 of the Bombay Civil Services Rules, which Rules had been adopted by the State of Saurashtra with some modifications, runs as follows Except as otherwise provided in the other clauses of this rule, the date of compulsory retirement of a Government servant,, other than an inferior servant, is the date on which he attains the age of 55 years. He may be retained in service after the date

anchor.surface_text: Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850, no order of dismissal, .removal or reduction shall be passed on a member, of a Service  other than an order based on facts which led to his conviction in a criminal court  unless he has been informed in writing of the grounds on which it is proposed to take action, and has been afforded an adequate opportuni- ty of defending himself. The grounds on which it is pro- posed to take action shall be reduced to the form of a definite charge or charges, which shall be communicated to the person charged together with a, statement of the allega- tions on which each charge is based and of any other circum- stances which it is proposed to take into consideration in passing orders on the case. He shall be required, within a reasonable time, to put in a written statement of his de- fence and to state whether he desires to be heard in person.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the stand taken by the respondent in the Court below was that an order retiring an officer before the age of superannuation was in substance one of dismissal or removal and must, in order to be valid, satisfy the requirements of Art. 311 2 , and that R. 165-A, in so far as it authorised the Government to terminate the service without any reason and without any enquiry was repugnant to Art. 311 2 , and was therefore ultra vires. This contention found favour with the learned Judges in the Court below.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the real criterion for deciding whether an order terminating the services of a servant is one of dismissal or removal is to ascertain whether it involves any loss of benefits previously earned. holdings.text: The real criterion for deciding whether an order terminating the services of a servant is one of dismissal or removal is to ascertain whether it involves any loss of benefits previously earned.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the real criterion for deciding whether an order terminating the services of a servant is one of dismissal or removal is to ascertain whether it involves any loss of benefits previously earned. Applying this test, an order under R. 165-A cannot be held to be one of dismissal or removal, as it does not entail forfeiture of the proportion- ate pension due for past services.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 311(2) protects against punitive actions entailing forfeiture of accrued benefits like pension; retirement allows proportionate pension, distinguishing it from dismissal/removal.

holdings.text: Applying this test, an order under R. 165-A cannot be held to be one of dismissal or removal, as it does not entail forfeiture of the proportionate pension due for past services.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this test, an order under R. 165-A cannot be held to be one of dismissal or removal, as it does not entail forfeiture of the proportion- ate pension due for past services. Does it make any difference in the position, as is contended by the respondent, that R. 165-A provides, unlike Note I to art. 465-A in Shyam Lal's case that the power is not to be exercised except in cases of misconduct or inefficiency ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of loss of benefits test to R.165-A; no penal consequences as pension proportionate to service preserved.

holdings.text: The provision in R. 165-A limiting exercise to public interest cases like inefficiency or dishonesty is departmental instruction only, not imposing fetter or requiring formal enquiry; rule confers absolute power.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the provision in R. 165-A on which the respondent relies does not, on its true construction, impose any fetter on the power previously conferred on the State in terms absolute, to terminate the services of its servant without assigning any reason. It is really in the nature of depart- mental instructions to be followed when action is proposed to be taken under, that rule, and makes it clear that the enquiry into the charges is only for the satisfaction of the authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive construction: grounds provide background for internal satisfaction, not formal basis triggering Art.311(2) enquiry; distinguishes from punitive cases.

holdings.text: While in retirement, misconduct/inefficiency furnish background only with optional enquiry for satisfaction; in dismissal/removal, they are basis requiring formal enquiry under natural justice and Art.311(2).

anchor.surface_text: in the case of dismissal or removal, they form the very basis on which the order is made and the enquiry thereon must be formal, and must satisfy the rules of natural justice and the requirements of Art. 311 2 . It should be added that questions of the above character could arise only when the rules fix both an age of superannuation and an age for compulsory

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retirement non-punitive (no loss of benefits); grounds not charge/imputation requiring defence; follows Shyam Lal.

holdings.text: Where there is no rule fixing age of compulsory retirement, or servant retired before prescribed age, it is dismissal/removal under Art.311(2).

anchor.surface_text: It should be added that questions of the above character could arise only when the rules fix both an age of superannuation and an age for compulsory retirement and the services of a civil servant are terminated between these two points of time. But where there is no rule fixing the age of compulsory retirement, or if there is one and the servant is retired before the age prescribed therein, then that can be regarded only as dismissal or removal within Art. 311 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only between fixed ages can retirement be non-punitive; outside, punitive.

holdings.text: R. 165-A is not violative of Art. 311(2) and is intra vires, and the impugned order dated October 30, 1952 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that R. 165-A is Dot violative of Art. 311 2  and is intra vires, and that the impugned order dated October 30, 1952, passed in exer- cise of the power conferred thereby is valid. A contention was also raised for the respondent that under the rules of service in force in the State of Junagadh, the age of superannuation was 60, that art. XVI of the Instrument of Accession

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines loss of benefits test, construction of rule, following Shyam Lal; no Art.311(2) protection needed.

holdings.text: No such claim under Junagadh rules and Art. XVI Instrument of Accession was put forward in the writ petition, too late to raise.

anchor.surface_text: But no such claim was put forward in the writ petition, and it is now too late to raise it. In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the lower Court is set aside, and the petition of the respondent is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: contention not pleaded in original writ; cannot raise first time in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the real criterion for deciding whether an order terminating the services of a servant is one of dismissal or removal is to ascertain whether it involves any loss of benefits previously earned. Applying this test, an order under R. 165-A cannot be held to be one of dismissal or removal, as it does not entail forfeiture of the proportion- ate pension due for past services.
In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the lower Court is set aside, and the petition of the respondent is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the provision in R. 165-A on which the respondent relies does not, on its true construction, impose any fetter on the power previously conferred on the State in terms absolute, to terminate the services of its servant without assigning any reason. It is really in the nature of depart- mental instructions to be followed when action is proposed to be taken under, that rule, and makes it clear that the enquiry into the charges is only for the satisfaction of the authorities.
In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the lower Court is set aside, and the petition of the respondent is dismissed.
